body:
It seems that the fault was ours, our version of the druid-hdfs-storage extension that we built to make Druid works in the previous versions doesn't work anymore. Indexing seems to work fine, sorry for the noise :)

Nit: Tranquillity seems still doing https://github.com/druid-io/tranquility/blob/master/core/src/main/scala/com/metamx/tranquility/druid/DruidEnvironment.scala#L28 that shouldn't be done anymore with Druid 0.11 afaics.
@leventov Is there anything I can do to make progress here? Thank you.

Since it sounds like we want to remove the legacy code at some point, I don't think it makes sense to put too much effort into factoring it nicely -- what makes more sense is to focus on making sure the newer code path is understandable, and that things will still make sense after the legacy code path is removed. If refactoring is the best way to accomplish that, then I say go for it.

I see that this time the strict compilation failed:
/home/travis/build/druid-io/druid/extensions-core/datasketches/src/test/java/io/druid/query/aggregation/datasketches/tuple/ArrayOfDoublesSketchToStringPostAggregatorTest.java:42: error: [SelfEquals] Testing an object for equality with itself will always be true.
    final boolean equalsSelf = postAgg1.equals(postAgg1); 

The previous version passed this check.
I would think I should revert the body of the tests to the previous version and put suppress warnings on the whole method instead.

No, you should add second suppression to the statement:
```java
@SuppressWarnings({"EqualsWithItself", "SelfEquals"})
```
Now the inspection build passes, but CI builds fail because of some timeout. Seems unrelated to the module in question.

It might be worth looking into CRD and Operators:
https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/access-kubernetes-api/extend-api-custom-resource-definitions/
https://coreos.com/blog/introducing-operators.html
https://github.com/coreos/etcd-operator

They allow you to instrument your deployments with custom code.

Hi, if my understanding of google pubsub is correct, you need to use a Pull based method. In other words this is not up to Druid, Druid allows both since the choice is depending on the what the queue/streaming system supports.
@a2l007 thanks. I left one comment. Also would you check the CI build failure?

It does seem a little weird to me to use the metadata store to hold split chunks of a large binary payload across multiple rows.

This would be a bigger design change, but I wonder if it would be better to keep the task action audit logs in deep storage instead, in a per-task file keyed by task ID. 

It doesn't look like Druid uses this audit table internally for any internal decision making.

Thanks for your comments @jihoonson  @b-slim 
I squashed commits into this PR with the review comments implemented.
The build seems to fail and I don't think it is do with these changes. Not sure what's wrong
@Caroline1000 Thanks! could you please fill the CLA http://druid.io/community/cla.html

Hmm, I see that Spark already updated to 1.10.0: https://github.com/apache/spark/commit/cac9b1dea1bb44fa42abf77829c05bf93f70cf20

Lets bump Druid as well to 1.10.0

Added a new test using EasyMock.

I was tempted to use jimfs for providing a disk to test against, unfortunately the codes still uses `File` instead of `Path` in most places, and updating that globally would probably be far beyond the scope of a small bug fix.

BTW: Would there be any disadvantage in changing `File`s to `Path`s, beside the needed work and double checking for subtle behavior changes?

Providing a sha256 hash to the last druid releases should be fairly easy in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/releases. It will take no time for the developers and it should give some relief to whoever wants to trust the binaries downloaded by static.druid.io.
All green here: https://travis-ci.org/Fokko/druid/builds/378663397

> api/src/main/java/io/druid/data/input/impl/prefetch
> PrefetchSqlFirehoseFactory.java (1)
> 252: initObjects() The declared exception IOException is never thrown in method implementations

Please check the TeamCity build failure too.
@varaga thanks. I left one more comment for doc. Also, would you please fill CLA (http://druid.io/community/cla.html)?
@QubitPi thanks. As @Dylan1312 said, this will be fixed in 0.12.1. Closing this issue.
Thanks @jihoonson  I have fixed the build.
@a2l007 thanks. I'll merge this tomorrow unless any other committers have comments.
Thanks @b-slim , I've filled it out.

@jihoonson  - Done with CLA & the comment !
Can you point me to understand the release cycles?
Looks good to me overall. Please check the build failure.

We have a regular release cycle for major releases per 3 months. Our next feature freeze is supposed to be around July 7th. After that, we will discuss our next major release (0.13.0), build and test maybe several RCs, and finally make an official release.

> This would be a bigger design change, but I wonder if it would be better to keep the task action audit logs in deep storage instead, in a per-task file keyed by task ID.

That's a good point. It might be a good idea if we need to store audit logs. 
But, even before thinking about this design change, I wonder what's the use case of `http://<OVERLORD_IP>:<port>/druid/indexer/v1/task/{taskId}/segments` API which is the only place reading the audit logs to get a list of segments inserted by a task. Why do users need to get a list of segments generated by a task? One use case I can imagine is that some users may want to revert changes made by a task, but I think it would be better to provide an API for reverting rather than returning a list of segments generated by a task.

@gianm any thoughts?

> That's a good point. It might be a good idea if we need to store audit logs.
> But, even before thinking about this design change, I wonder what's the use case of http://<OVERLORD_IP>:<port>/druid/indexer/v1/task/{taskId}/segments API which is the only place reading the audit logs to get a list of segments inserted by a task. Why do users need to get a list of segments generated by a task? One use case I can imagine is that some users may want to revert changes made by a task, but I think it would be better to provide an API for reverting rather than returning a list of segments generated by a task.

Honestly, the only reason that API exists is because when I was originally building the task action system, I thought it might be cool to see what segments a task created. I didn't have a specific use case in mind. I am not sure if anyone in the community has built anything interesting around it since then or not.

> This would be a bigger design change, but I wonder if it would be better to keep the task action audit logs in deep storage instead, in a per-task file keyed by task ID.

Storing audit logs in deep storage (like task reports) seems like a better idea to me than the metadata store. I suppose each one would need to be its own file. I would support moving them there, and maybe making them optional. I think they should be off by default -- they aren't too useful and they'll create a lot of extra files on deep storage (which people sometimes try to minimize, especially if they're on a system like hdfs where it's tough to scale to large numbers of files).
Added another idea to actually use `Path`s on a limited scope. There should be no change in behavior, but please have a second look at this.
@b-slim @drcrallen Thanks for the review, I addressed the comments (except for the one about strong guarantees, not sure what specific guarantees that comment refers to)
@gianm Could you please review this pr?
@mkuthan @jihoonson Hi. It's late comment. I missed mention. @mkuthan 's idea and an outline described is good. Please go ahead If you want to progress.
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/4494 related
@nishantmonu51 thanks!
Hi @nateMJ, every supervisor should have its ID which is the name of dataSource where the data is ingested to.
Druid supports UTF-8 encoding, so I am surprised it didn't work. In fact I have seen it ingest Chinese characters properly before, so maybe there is some decoding problem. What was the data format?
You could use segment metadata queries if you know ahead of time which intervals you are indexing for.

The dependency to jimfs is only for testing and will not influence production systems.

The problem with the test is, that we need to simulate a situation in which a file system is "almost" full. We cannot really directly use the actual file system for that, because we have no control over how big it is and how much is free there.
As far as I see there are two solutions: either faking those values using something like EasyMock, or using a dedicated file system we have control over.

My first commit fixes the issues. The second one implements a EasyMock solution and the third one replaces it with the jimfs solution.

The jimfs solution has the advantage that we have a real file system, we can add multiple segments to it and the free space will change accordingly.

Yes, most of the code is currently written using the old pre-JDK7 IO system (i.e. `File`) which is a bit limited. The "new" (i.e. since JDK7) NIO system (i.e. `Path`) is more flexible and also provides support for other file system like jimfs. (You can switch between both APIs by using `.toFile()` and `.toPath()`, which works well as long as they refer to the default file system.)

I tend to use the newer NIO system for more flexibility and especially jimfs for more realistic tests.
If you worry too much about this kind of change it would be perfectly fine to drop the last commit and go with the EasyMock solution.

Maybe the change could also start a discussion to leverage the code to more modern java. Switching from `File` to `Path` could easily be done step by step, but I understand if you are concerned about possible subtle changes in behavior.
@b-slim @drcrallen Can you take another look when you get a chance?

Hi guys, we are currently using Druid 12.0 and Kafka together in our production environment. Its not very common to loose the Kafka offsets but it could be due to server failures etc. So having a backup plan in druid would be highly recommended
Have you considered Kubernetes? My guess is that it can replace Zookeeper as well.
Also consider adding support for k8s as full resource manager, i.e. replacing zookeeper for service discovery etc. It would add neat features like restart strategies for example.
@PrashantN86 you can use Hive Master branch, or https://github.com/apache/hive/tree/branch-3.0  or HDP https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP2/HDP-2.6.5/index.html
@jon-wei @clintropolis would you take another look?

> Storing audit logs in deep storage (like task reports) seems like a better idea to me than the metadata store. I suppose each one would need to be its own file. I would support moving them there, and maybe making them optional. I think they should be off by default -- they aren't too useful and they'll create a lot of extra files on deep storage (which people sometimes try to minimize, especially if they're on a system like hdfs where it's tough to scale to large numbers of files). 

That sounds good to me. I'll update this PR soon. Thanks @jon-wei and @gianm.

> posting a supervisor without a datasource name or kafka topic name posts successfully but can't be deleted later.

What do you mean by `posting a supervisor without a datasource name`? Does it mean `${datasource}` was empty when you posted the above supervisor spec?

You can't submit a supervisor spec without dataSource name. Druid internally checks it and returns an error if it's empty.

Confirmed you can post a supervisor spec with a dataSource as an empty string, at least in Druid 0.12.0.

To remove the supervisor I updated the specId in the metadata store (in the druid_supervisors table), restarted the overlord and then shut it down using the updated specId.
@Dylan1312 thank you for reporting! This is definitely a bug.
@Dylan1312 would you make a patch for this bug? I think we should check `dataSource` is null or empty in the constructor of `DataSchema`.

@michas2 thanks. Using `Path` APIs looks good to me, but `jimfs` looks not being developed actively for more than 2 years. The last release was Feb 12, 2016. I think it would be better to not depend on such inactive projects if possible. What do you think?
@Dylan1312 oh, you already raised a PR! I'll take a look. Thanks!
Fixed in #5785.

@jihoonson The `Path` API change is the only critical one, because it actually touches production code.

Sure `jimfs` looks a bit inactive, but remember it is only used in test code and it implements no more than a pretty simple filesystem - guess not many new features are needed once it is doing its job.

If you are aware of a different/newer/better implementation providing the same functionality, I have no problem switching to it.

But since it is small, test only, and provides the needed functionality, I have no problem going with `jimfs` for now.

Got the solution,i was using wrong port number.
worked with 8081 port.(Coordinator)
Thank you
@gianm could you take a look at this PR?
@gianm could you also take a look at this PR?

@b-slim 
Think about this: 
I want to aggregate the data into a one-day granularity at ingestion time. Obviously it is related to the timezone. The definition of one day is different at different timezone. In this situation, forcing user to use UTC makes things weird.

Best regards,
Ryan

This issue (segments not being loaded because they don't match the load rule) also happens with 'future' segments, since interval load rules calculate from current server time and exclude segments that begin later. This is made worse by incremental publishing, since the time the segment metadata gets read and processed by the coordinator now happens earlier instead of at the end of the task.

@michas2 the `Path` API change must be fine because they are compatible with the previous codes.

My concern is using `jimfs`. Using it in unit tests doesn't mean that it's trivial or not important. I think it's important as much as production code and we should consider the maintenance issue when adding a dependency. For example, what if we find an unknown bug while using `jimfs`? We might make a PR for the bug, but should wait for the release containing the fix. It might be not a big issue if they release frequently, but they hasn't released for more than 2 years. 

> If you are aware of a different/newer/better implementation providing the same functionality, I have no problem switching to it.

As you already tried, you can do the similar test using EasyMock. Is there any concern about it? I think mocking file system behavior should have no issue here because we're testing the behavior of segmentCache of Druid, not underlying file system.

@jihoonson I personally would prefer to test against some actual file system, but I think the point is to fix the actual bug. - It's perfectly fine to go without jimfs.

I reverted the last commit. Now we are back to the EasyMock solution. (For the given test that should be good enough.)
Can we get this merged? Thanks!
Would someone review this? @gianm @jon-wei @nishantmonu51 @b-slim
@a2l007 thanks for reminding. Merged.
@niketh I'll review in a few days. Would you check the Travis failure?

@davidkeeper What version of Druid are you running?
@jon-wei  we use the latest version: v0.12.0,   and avatica version is :  1.10.0

@jon-wei pls mention that the sql is ordered by __time. When i delete "order by __time", the right responses are returned, so i think it may contain a bug about using "ordered by __time" in druid sql of JDBC.

@huhusuperma    Here we use time_id as timestamp.  and if remove order by __time instead of 'group by time_id, res_ins_id order by time_id desc'  that's OK, but inner query is change to groupby query, cause low performance.

@mkuthan I got a little bit misunderstanding, so please describe more detail about your question with example. Is it not work with [it](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/19f359957f129c9f240d122e39bbd336390f6475/server/src/main/java/io/druid/server/log/EmittingRequestLogger.java#L80)?
It's another question: It's mandatory to use? I think it's proper using optionally because default value of ```druid.request.logging.type``` is ```noop```. ([docs](http://druid.io/docs/latest/configuration/index.html))
Create an issue (https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/new), not a PR

@dkhwangbo  As long as [EmittingRequestLogger.toMap](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/19f359957f129c9f240d122e39bbd336390f6475/server/src/main/java/io/druid/server/log/EmittingRequestLogger.java#L80) returns empty map, kafka emitter emits only empty JSON structure instead of query payload with stats.

EmittingRequestLogger.toMap method is not implemented because there is no way to map complex RequestLogEvent structure into flat map. There is polymorphic query object and map like query stats in the RequestLogEvent class.
Hey @ThuyLeVn what version of Java do you have installed? I think AMI comes with Java7 out of the box whereas Druid requires Java8

Could you run `java -version` to check? The screenshot shows a docker image running java8 but your original screenshot shows a bash prompt indicating that the java command wasn't run inside that container.

If you mean ingestion tasks, submitting new tasks should be much the same as normal. POSTing the JSON spec at the overlord running on port 8090.

Just digging a little, this looks to have been introduced in #4852. I think the change results in the query_fail_time being evaluated before the default timeout has been put into the query context.
@drcrallen Did you have any more comments on this?

@jihoonson is this ready for user testing? I would be interested in building a release with this and trying it out.

For context we are struggling with Hadoop and would really like to drop it in favour of native batch indexing.

@josephglanville good to hear! This PR is ready for testing. I've tested this in our cluster and there was no issue so far except https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5751. https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5751 is not an issue of this PR, but should be resolved and applied together to avoid segment insertion failure to metastore when ingesting lots of data.

Please note that the current patch for https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5751 is not ready because we decided to change its design. However, it should work if you want to apply it as it is.

Can you share the query and the results you are getting ? 
It is quite possible that between the two queries tranquility might have sent more events and hence the results are different.
I didn't quite figure out the issue but a redeploy of the coordinator node fixed it.
@jihoonson Will this fix be backported to 12.1?

@michas2 well, 0.12.1 is basically a release to fix bugs introduced in 0.12.0 and we're already testing rc1, so we won't make another rc for only this bug. However, it can be included if we need to make another rc to fix a regression.

@nishantmonu51  thanks for your reply.
> 1.  I have a simple query which is `select * from datasource where A='a'`, and the query result should be only one.
> 2.  First time , i do it then this request redirect to peon task1 and have a result with null.
> 3.  Second, i do it again,then this request redirect to peon task2 and have a right result.
 
What i mean is that this query should redirect to `peon task1 and peon task2`.

@nishantmonu51  thanks, we have solved it, it's our fault, because  `linear shardSpec ` lead to druid can't merge segment automatically, so we modify this to `none shardSpec` in tranquility, then broker use  `SingleElementPartitionChunk` to build timeline rather than `LinearPartitionChunk`.

@gianm if I recall the broker only pulls per-segment results if it is asked to populate cache results. If you set the broker to use cache but not populate, it should try to pull what it can, but then push down the un-matched stuff to the historicals.
